DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Facility went out of business/sold on 05/11/2012.

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Mechanical Integrity inspection of refrigeration system

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
See Attachment
Merchants Terminal Corporation
Risk Management Program
Executive Summary 

1. General accidental release and prevention policy of Merchants Terminal

In this frozen food distribution center we utilize anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant. Anhydrous ammonia is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency. The same properties that make ammonia a valuable refrigerant also makes its necessary to observe certain safety percautions during its use to prevent exposure to our workers, the surrounding community and the environment. It is our policy at Merchants Terminal Corporation to implement the requirments of the Risk Management Program by manageing and operating this facility in full compliance with all applicable federal and state regulations. The objective is to minimize the risk of an accidental ammonia release. Safety depends directly on our proper handling of ammonia. Our plant personnel have been trained on the equipment operating procedures and various safety devices that are incorporated in our facilty to prevent the possibility of accidental releases.

2.   Stationary source and regulated substane handles.

Merchants Terminal Corporation, 1811 Cabin Branch, Landover, Maryland is responsible for the storagre and distribution of various frozen food products. Merchants Terminal is located in an industrial park approximatelt 4 mile north-east of Washington D.C. In addition to our facility the surrounding community houses other commercial businesses as well as residential areas. There are approximently 24 employees at this facility which includes hourly and salary personnel. This facility receives and prepares shipment of frozen and refrigerated food products via tractor trailers approximently 10 hours a day, five days a week.

The potentially hazardous chemical used at this facility is Anhydrous Ammonia. Ammonia in a liquid or vapor can be found in process equipment thoughout, piping and vessels throughout the facilty. 

The potentail haz

ards that could lead to an acciidetial release of ammonia include, but are not limited to, euipment failure, damage to piping, damage to equipment, human error, etc.

Although ammonia is a colorless, tasteless liquid, its dominant characteristic is it's pingent, distinct order. Persons exposed to ammonia will not voluntarily stay in areas of even small concentrations, although these levels would not normally result in any health risks. Risks for acciential exposure to ammonia n a vapor state sre irritation to the eyes, nose, throat. The extent of irriataion is dependant of level of concentation and durtaion of exposure. Ammnia is classified non-flammable by the DOT. Ammonia will burn, but onlt ia a very narrow concentration level, when accompanied with a constant ignition source.

The normal inventory of level of ammonia used at this facility is 18,000 pounds.



3. The following administrative and engineering controls are in place at this facility. These controls are designed to eliminate, or reduce the possibility of an ammonia release.

* Electronic ammonia detectors in compressor, vessel, and warehouse areas. Alarms tie into ADT security system Computer system activates a local audible alarm indicating an ammonia leak in the monitored areas. ADT notifies designated facility personnel, via phone and pager, of a potential problem detected in the system.

* High level switches are configured to all high and low temp vessels, which shut down compressor operation and liquid make-up solenoids in the event of a high liquid condition.

* All compressor are configured with pre-alarms and safety cutout on all critical system pressures and temp.

* Safety relief valves are present on all vessels , compressors, condensers, oil separators to prevent over- pressurization

* Periodic maintenance program is established to ensure the process equipment  in maintain in optimum mechanical and operational condition.

* Emergency shutdown procedures are in place to activate the shut

down in the event of an emergency.

4. Five- year accident history

 Heavy snowfall lead a roof collaspe on 2-22-2003. No ammonia piping was damaged to the point of release. No injuries resulted and an ammonia released caused by a leaking flange on solenoid valve was contained on-site.

5. Emergency Response Program

The purpose of the Merchants Terminal Emergency Action Plan is to:

     1. Minimize exposure to our employees and the surrounding community in the event of a    ammonia release or spill. 

      2. Assure the safe emergency evacuation of the facility.

      3. Provide for prompt medical medical attention 

      
Our EAP currently meets OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38 compliance.
